title: Does the concept of "pure freedom" exist in reality or esoteric teachings? Analysis of determinism and the unity of universal law.
first_phrase: In the previous paragraphs, Nir critiques the concept of "pure freedom" and highlights the relative control of freedom in social and moral phenomena. He argues that life is not distinguished from dead matter by an arbitrary absence of laws but by different quality laws. In this final part, Nir suggests that the terms of the contrast between determinism and freedom become obsolete if we acknowledge the deterministic laws behind everything in nature, even behind esotericism. He uses phenomena of sovereign prediction as a concomitant argument and concludes with a speculative consideration.

last_phrase: To summarize, life is subject to certain laws, whether they are finalistic or immanent. The esoteric view suggests that science can discover external deterministic laws that reflect internal spiritual laws. In this way, the contrast between determinism and freedom disappears. Therefore, to focus on the problem of freedom is to misunderstand the true nature of time and reality. Time is a mode of human knowledge, and only temporal phenomena are subject to change. The metaphysical reality transcends time and is beyond the concepts of freedom or necessity.
